content: The VA Vision Scholars Act of 2007 establishes the Visual Impairment and Orientation and Mobility Professionals Education Assistance Program under Chapter 80 of title 38, United States Code. The VA Vision Scholars Act of 2007 establishes a scholarship program to provide financial assistance for individuals studying visual impairment or orientation and mobility. The VA Vision Scholars Act of 2007 establishes a scholarship program to increase the supply of qualified blind rehabilitation specialists for the Department and the Nation. The program provides financial assistance for individuals studying visual impairment or orientation and mobility at accredited educational institutions. The Secretary will publicize the scholarship program to educational institutions. The VA Vision Scholars Act of 2007 establishes a scholarship program to increase the supply of qualified blind rehabilitation specialists for the Department and the Nation. The program provides financial assistance for individuals studying visual impairment or orientation and mobility at accredited educational institutions, with a focus on institutions with high numbers of Hispanic students and Historically Black Colleges and Universities. Applicants must submit an application and agreement for participation, agreeing to serve a period of obligated service in return for educational payment. The program provides financial assistance for individuals studying visual impairment or orientation and mobility at accredited educational institutions. Applicants must submit an application and agreement for participation, agreeing to serve a period of obligated service in return for educational payment. The Secretary distributes application and agreement forms with a fair summary of rights and liabilities, as well as terms and conditions for participation. The VA Vision Scholars Act of 2007 establishes a scholarship program for blind rehabilitation specialists. The Secretary approves individuals for the program and notifies them in writing. Participants receive financial assistance to cover tuition and fees for their studies. The VA Vision Scholars Act of 2007 provides financial assistance for a dual degree or certification program, with tuition and fees limited to the minimum credit hours required. Assistance can supplement other educational aid, as long as the total does not exceed tuition and fees for the academic year. The VA Vision Scholars Act of 2007 provides financial assistance for students, with a maximum limit of $15,000 for full-time students and $45,000 overall. Part-time students receive assistance based on the ratio of their coursework to full-time coursework. The VA Vision Scholars Act of 2007 offers financial assistance up to $45,000 over a maximum duration of six years. Participants must sign a written agreement with the Secretary, agreeing to accept and maintain enrollment for the financial assistance provided under the program. The VA Vision Scholars Act of 2007 provides financial assistance up to $45,000 over six years. Participants must maintain enrollment, academic standing, and serve as a full-time employee in the Department for three years after completing the program. The VA Vision Scholars Act of 2007 offers financial assistance for education. Participants must complete a program and receive a degree or certificate. Repayment is required if the agreement terms are not met, except in authorized circumstances. The Secretary will establish repayment procedures and may grant exceptions. Waiver or suspension of obligations is possible for noncompliance due to uncontrollable circumstances. The Secretary may waive or suspend obligations for noncompliance due to uncontrollable circumstances or in the best interest of the United States. Repayment to the Secretary is considered a debt owed to the United States, not discharged by bankruptcy within five years of the agreement termination. Title 38 and part V of title 38 are amended by inserting a new item after the chapter 79 item. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs must implement chapter 80 of title 38, United States Code, within six months of this Act's enactment.
